entry.content:
Instrument Parts

  • DingÂ - Central dome/tone field in the middle
  • Tone field/Note fieldÂ - Tuned areas that produce notes when struck
  • ShoulderÂ - Area surrounding the central ding
  • GuÂ - Resonance opening on the bottom (sound hole)
  • DimpleÂ - Highlighted or recessed areas in the center of each tone field
  • Top shellÂ - Upper half of the handpan
  • Bottom shellÂ - Lower half of the handpan
  • Rim/EdgeÂ - Non-resonant part holding the two halves together
  • InterspaceÂ - Areas between tone fields

Instrument Types & Variations

  • HandpanÂ - Generic term for the instrument
  • Hang/Hang DrumÂ - PANArt's trademarked original instrumentÂ 
  • PantamÂ - Alternative term combining "pan" and "ghatam"
  • CupolaÂ - Rare umbrella term for handpans
  • SpacedrumÂ - Brand name by Metal Sounds
  • Double SiderÂ - Handpan with tone fields on both sides
  • Mutant HandpanÂ - Instruments with more than 10 tone fields
  • Bottom NotesÂ - Tone fields on the underside

Materials

  • Stainless steelÂ - Rust-resistant steel
  • Nitrided steelÂ - Nitrogen-treated steel
  • Raw steel/Unprocessed steelÂ - Basic steel form

Musical Terms

  • Scale/TuningÂ - Selection of notes available
  • Diatonic scaleÂ - Seven-note subset
  • Chromatic scaleÂ - All 12 pitchesÂ 
  • Major scaleÂ - Perceived as "happier"
  • Minor scaleÂ - Perceived as "mysterious"
  • ChordÂ - Three or more notes played simultaneously
  • ArpeggioÂ - Chord notes played sequentially
  • Overtones/HarmonicsÂ - Additional tones above the fundamental
  • OctaveÂ - Note eight steps higher
  • Flat (b)Â - Note one semitone lower
  • Sharp (#)Â - Note one semitone higher

Sound Qualities

  • SustainÂ - How long notes ring after being struck
  • Timbre/Tone colorÂ - Quality/character of sound
  • Dynamics/Dynamic rangeÂ - Volume spectrum from quietest to loudest
  • Helmholtz resonanceÂ - Air resonance in the cavity

Technical Terms

  • CrosstalkÂ - Unwanted activation of other tone fields
  • Sympathetic activationÂ - Desired activation of other fields
  • Impedance/Phase cancellationÂ - Sound waves canceling each other
  • IsolationÂ - Preventing unwanted vibrations between fields
  • StabilityÂ - Ability to maintain tuning

Playing Techniques

  • SlapÂ - Light strike with soft hand parts
  • Knock/TapÂ - Striking with knuckles
  • TakÂ - Percussive sound from striking interspaces
  • Shoulder tonesÂ - Sounds from the shoulder area
  • Singing the dingÂ - Rubbing technique on central field
  • BuskingÂ - Street performance

Musical Concepts

  • PatternÂ - Sequence of notes
  • Groove/RhythmÂ - Specific way a piece is played
  • Beat/TempoÂ - Speed measured in BPM
  • Time signatureÂ - Beats per measure
  • Measure/BarÂ - Musical "sentence"
  • MetronomeÂ - Device for keeping steady tempo

Other Terms

  • IdiophoneÂ - Instrument producing sound through body vibrationÂ 
  • GatheringÂ - Meeting of handpan players and makers
  • Sound sculptureÂ - Artistic term for handpansÂ
